section.name: QuickStart
section.p: This quickstart is a small guide to get you up and running to start using Wicket within minutes. Currently only Eclipse is supported, but if you have another IDE you'd like to see quickstart support for, don't hesitate to contribute!

subsection.name: Summary
subsection.p: For the more knowledgeable developers, here's a short list of steps to quickstart your Wicket development. All these steps are explained in more detail below.

ul.li: download the quickstart project for your IDE (currently only Eclipse is supported)
create new Java project in Eclipse, using previous project name
run the QuickStart class (Run as - Java application)

subsection.p: Below some pointers are given to proceed from here.

subsection.name: The quickstart project
subsection.p: Next you need to download the quickstart distribution project from our sourceforge site.
Unzip the distribution into your Eclipse workspace (which is typically located under C:\eclipse\workspace).
Rename the directory that was just created to your required project name. In the following the directory name is renamed to 'foobar'.

subsection.name: Configuring Eclipse
subsection.p: Now it is time to start Eclipse, if you haven't done so already. Select the workspace where you have installed the Wicket quickstart project. In order to have Eclipse import your project we will create a new Java project using the directory name of your project.

ul.li: Start the 'New project' wizard in Eclipse.

Enter in the 'project name' box the name of your directory (chosen in the directory rename action of before). Notice the text at the bottom of the dialog saying The specified external location already exists. If a project is created in this location, the wizard will automatically try to detect existing sources and class files and configure the classpath appropriately.
Leave all other options on their default values and click 'Finish'.

subsection.name: Running the application
subsection.p: The application has an internal webserver (Jetty) which can be used to quickly develop webapplications. All you need to do is to run the application and point your browser to the webserver running from within Eclipse.

ul.li: Start the Jetty server by right-clicking on the src/main/java directory in the project and selecting the menu: 'Run as - Java application'. If Eclipse prompts you for a main class, browse to the class named 'QuickStart'.
Point the browser to the local Jetty server: link to your local Jetty server.

section.name: Further development
section.p: This section gives some pointers on where to go now.

ul.li: take a look at the examples
find more information in the manual
find more information on the wiki

subsection.name: Jetty configuration
subsection.p: The Jetty configuration file is located in the project directory:

Jetty is started on port 8081 in order to avoid conflicts with other installed application servers (for instance Tomcat). This way it is easier to test with different application servers. This can be configured in the configuration file.
See the Jetty documentation for information on how to configure Jetty.
Jetty is started in the main-method of the wicket.quickstart.QuickStart class.

subsection.name: Customizing the application
subsection.p: The main page definitions can be found in the src/main/java/Index.html HTML file and the src/main/java/wicket.quickstart.Index.java class.
